body:
The missing window decoration is caused by the renaming of Wayland interfaces. The decorations are using `wp_viewporter` which was previously named `wl_scaler`. However, neither of these interfaces are available on Gnome 3.28 and I believe that the new `xdg_wm_base` is supposed to include this functionality.
Is there a chance that the resizing functionality will make use of the `xdg_wm_base`?

GNOME should get it once they resolve this issue: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/issues/132
For Kwin I haven’t been able to find a bug report, you may want to report one yourself.
As for Weston, I don’t plan on supporting old versions as it isn’t a desktop environment and thus not something most users will end up using as their daily driver, and because this `wl_scaler` protocol would have to be embedded in GLFW’s sources rather than pulled from wayland-protocols.

For Kwin and possibly other compositors, a totally different approach could be used, where GLFW would instead ask the compositor to decorate our window itself, I’m only waiting for the protocol to end up in wayland-protocols, see: https://github.com/glfw/glfw/pull/1161#issuecomment-361238461

Edit: I added a mention about the protocol requirement in the compatibility document: https://github.com/glfw/glfw/commit/617a322bd88c1b27f1fd7d05dc3723b6c5461a68

With Wayland Protocols 1.15, a new XDG-Decoration has been added, which means there is now a common way to ask for decorators to draw decorations. https://lists.freedesktop.org/archives/wayland-devel/2018-July/038831.html
But it is not guaranteed that desktop shells will implement this. Maybe there should be an alternative way to draw client-side decorations.

gracicot, thanks for the notification, I’ll look for a compositor to develop this against.

christianrauch, there already is one, as long as `wp_viewporter` is supported.

I know that the viewporter is an official and stable protocol extension. But the real problem I wanted to make aware of in this issue is that it is not (yet) supported in major desktop environments like Gnome and KDE.
It might be better to manually implement this functionality, using the core protocol only, to support more desktop environments.

issue.body:

This is what I end up with in the journal:

issue.title: Add support for xdg-decoration

repository.name: glfw
repository.description: A multi-platform library for OpenGL, OpenGL ES, Vulkan, window and input

issue.body:
This allows compositors which prefer to draw the decorations around
clients to do so, rather than letting GLFW draw its own decorations.
The appearance is thus entirely subject to the compositor used, but
should generally be better than the current solid colour decorations we
have, which we continue to use when the compositor doesn’t support this
protocol or tells us to draw the decorations ourselves.

This new protocol has been tested against [wlroots](https://github.com/swaywm/wlroots)’s rootston compositor.

Fixes #1257.

body:
[xdg-decoration](https://cgit.freedesktop.org/wayland/wayland-protocols/tree/unstable/xdg-decoration/xdg-decoration-unstable-v1.xml) is now implemented in GLFW (as of #1341), adding support for server-side decorations in compositors implementing this protocol.

Neither GNOME nor KDE support it yet, so I’m reoppening this bug.

KDE, as of KWin 5.15, [now supports `xdg_decoration`](https://phabricator.kde.org/D17756), and GNOME [now supports `wp_viewporter`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/merge_requests/323), for the upcoming 3.32 release.

We can now close this issue as all relevant compositors now support one of these two protocols, if any user still doesn’t see decorations we can just tell them to update their compositor. 🙂

issue.title: Cannot create Window on Wayland
issue.body:
Tried this on Ubuntu 18.04, with Wayland (before logging in, select Wayland via the little menu next to the unlock button), and installing the glfw lib via `sudo apt install libglfw-wayland`.

This simple example fails:
```py
import glfw
glfw.init()
# glfw.ERROR_REPORTING = False
w = glfw.create_window(640, 480, "glfw window", None, None)
```

Traceback:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<tmp 1>", line 4, in <module>
    w = glfw.create_window(640, 480, "glfw window", None, None)
  File "/home/almar/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/glfw/__init__.py", line 1141, in create_window
    monitor, share)
  File "/home/almar/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/glfw/__init__.py", line 609, in errcheck
    _reraise(exc[1], exc[2])
  File "/home/almar/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/glfw/__init__.py", line 45, in _reraise
    raise exception.with_traceback(traceback)
  File "/home/almar/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/glfw/__init__.py", line 588, in callback_wrapper
    return func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/almar/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/glfw/__init__.py", line 800, in _raise_glfw_errors_as_exceptions
    raise GLFWError(message)
glfw.GLFWError: (65544) b'Wayland: Focusing a window requires user interaction'
```

If I uncomment the line to ignore errors, it works, except the window is undecorated.

Some context: https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/1121 seems to suggest that the error is more of a warning? See also  [these](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue+Focusing+a+window+requires+user+interaction). 

It looks like PyGLFW checks if there are errors and raises them as Python exceptions. Perhaps there should be a filter to ignore specific exceptions like this one?
